repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
According to the standard pointer arithmetic is only defined in these situations:
- `nullptr` ± 0 => `nullptr`
- P±N and N±P are pointers that point at an element of the same array with index I±N

`**nullptr**`** + N≠0 is undefined behavior** - even if you don't dereference the resulting pointer.

Since [InstCombine] icmp eq/ne (gep inbounds P, Idx..), null -> icmp eq/ne P, null) https://reviews.llvm.org/D66608 LLVM middle-end uses those guarantees for transformations and mis-compilations have been observed:
- https://lists.llvm.org/pipermail/llvm-commits/Week-of-Mon-20190826/687838.html
- https://github.com/google/filament/pull/1566


To prevent help weed out bugs before they lead to future miscompilations a new UBSAN check has been added: `nullptr-with-nonzero-offset`
- [UBSan][clang][compiler-rt] Applying non-zero offset to nullptr is undefined behaviour https://reviews.llvm.org/D67122

This new nullptr-with-nonzero-offset check fails on invocations of this macro. Fix the macro to avoid adding to NULL.

comment_data.body:
`typeof` isn't standard C so that's definitely not a suitable replacement.

Is there any evidence that we actually call this with `args==NULL` and `nargs!=0`? I believe such a call wouldn't be following Python vectorcall protocol so would be dodgy anyway.

I do wonder if it should be `arg+nargs` though to avoid the dereference?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -422,7 +422,7 @@ static int __Pyx_MergeKeywords(PyObject *kwdict, PyObject *source_mapping) {
 #if CYTHON_METH_FASTCALL
     #define __Pyx_Arg_FASTCALL(args, i) args[i]
     #define __Pyx_NumKwargs_FASTCALL(kwds) PyTuple_GET_SIZE(kwds)
-    #define __Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(args, nargs) (&args[nargs])
+    #define __Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(args, nargs) ({ typeof (args) _a = (args); _a ? (&_a[nargs]) : NULL;})

comment_data.body:
> `typeof` isn't standard C

It [is](https://thephd.dev/ever-closer-c23-improvements#typeof), since C23. :)

More seriously, as the [paper](http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg14/www/docs/n2927.htm) that added it describes, this is a ubiquitous function (however it is spelled), because compilers need that functionality to implement `sizeof`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -422,7 +422,7 @@ static int __Pyx_MergeKeywords(PyObject *kwdict, PyObject *source_mapping) {
 #if CYTHON_METH_FASTCALL
     #define __Pyx_Arg_FASTCALL(args, i) args[i]
     #define __Pyx_NumKwargs_FASTCALL(kwds) PyTuple_GET_SIZE(kwds)
-    #define __Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(args, nargs) (&args[nargs])
+    #define __Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(args, nargs) ({ typeof (args) _a = (args); _a ? (&_a[nargs]) : NULL;})

comment_data.body:
My mistake! It isn't part of the subset of the standards of C and C++ that Cython needs to be compatible with.

I also don't think it's hugely needed - I assume it's to avoid evaluating `arg` twice in the macro. But it's a macro that only Cython calls, and only with "simple" arguments, so that isn't a concern.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -422,7 +422,7 @@ static int __Pyx_MergeKeywords(PyObject *kwdict, PyObject *source_mapping) {
 #if CYTHON_METH_FASTCALL
     #define __Pyx_Arg_FASTCALL(args, i) args[i]
     #define __Pyx_NumKwargs_FASTCALL(kwds) PyTuple_GET_SIZE(kwds)
-    #define __Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(args, nargs) (&args[nargs])
+    #define __Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(args, nargs) ({ typeof (args) _a = (args); _a ? (&_a[nargs]) : NULL;})

comment_data.body: In the case that Cython is compiled with an address sanitizer, as might happen in a larger, integrated codebase, then this line will trigger irrespective of whether the macro is only called by Cython or not. That check can be disabled by wrapping this line with appropriate sanitizer override flags, or by disabling address sanitization for all of Cython - which seems risky.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -422,7 +422,7 @@ static int __Pyx_MergeKeywords(PyObject *kwdict, PyObject *source_mapping) {
 #if CYTHON_METH_FASTCALL
     #define __Pyx_Arg_FASTCALL(args, i) args[i]
     #define __Pyx_NumKwargs_FASTCALL(kwds) PyTuple_GET_SIZE(kwds)
-    #define __Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(args, nargs) (&args[nargs])
+    #define __Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(args, nargs) ({ typeof (args) _a = (args); _a ? (&_a[nargs]) : NULL;})

comment_data.body:
> I do wonder if it should be arg+nargs though to avoid the dereference?

Even this is undefined behavior if `nargs != 0`.

> `({ typeof (args) _a = (args); _a ? (&_a[nargs]) : NULL;})`

This uses gcc statement expressions, which is a non standard extension of C/C++. This is not available e.g. on MSVC. As noted by @h-vetinari typeof is not officially available until C23, even though it is available in all compilers. So this is definetly not usable here.

> Is there any evidence that we actually call this with args==NULL and nargs!=0? I believe such a call wouldn't be following Python vectorcall protocol so would be dodgy anyway.

Yes, as long as we call `PyVectorcall_NARGS` this should never be the case. Since this got caught by UBSan I think we should find out how this part of the code could even be called with `args==NULL` and `nargs!=0`, since this sounds VERY wrong.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -422,7 +422,7 @@ static int __Pyx_MergeKeywords(PyObject *kwdict, PyObject *source_mapping) {
 #if CYTHON_METH_FASTCALL
     #define __Pyx_Arg_FASTCALL(args, i) args[i]
     #define __Pyx_NumKwargs_FASTCALL(kwds) PyTuple_GET_SIZE(kwds)
-    #define __Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(args, nargs) (&args[nargs])
+    #define __Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(args, nargs) ({ typeof (args) _a = (args); _a ? (&_a[nargs]) : NULL;})

comment_data.body:
> irrespective of whether the macro is only called by Cython or not

My comment about "only called by Cython" was more that we don't have to worry about the macro arguments being evaluated twice (so don't have to put them in a temporary), since we know if isn't called with `__Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(++args,...)`or `__Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(some_really_expensive_function_call(),...)`.

> > Is there any evidence that we actually call this with `args==NULL` and `nargs!=0`? I believe such a call wouldn't be following Python vectorcall protocol so would be dodgy anyway.

> Yes, as long as we call `PyVectorcall_NARGS` this should never be the case. Since this got caught by UBSan I think we should find out how this part of the code could even be called with `args==NULL` and `nargs!=0`, since this sounds VERY wrong.

Yes - this is my view. The real issue is whatever is making these calls with a bad combination of arguments - I'd much rather have a diagnostic of that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -422,7 +422,7 @@ static int __Pyx_MergeKeywords(PyObject *kwdict, PyObject *source_mapping) {
 #if CYTHON_METH_FASTCALL
     #define __Pyx_Arg_FASTCALL(args, i) args[i]
     #define __Pyx_NumKwargs_FASTCALL(kwds) PyTuple_GET_SIZE(kwds)
-    #define __Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(args, nargs) (&args[nargs])
+    #define __Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL(args, nargs) ({ typeof (args) _a = (args); _a ? (&_a[nargs]) : NULL;})

commit.message:
__Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL: avoid triggering UB when adding non-zero to NULL (caught by UBSAN nullptr-with-nonzero-offset)

According to the standard pointer arithmetic is only defined in these situations:
- `nullptr` ± 0 => `nullptr`
- P±N and N±P are pointers that point at an element of the same array with index I±N

`**nullptr**`** + N≠0 is undefined behavior** - even if you don't dereference the resulting pointer.

Since [InstCombine] icmp eq/ne (gep inbounds P, Idx..), null -> icmp eq/ne P, null) https://reviews.llvm.org/D66608 LLVM middle-end uses those guarantees for transformations and mis-compilations have been observed:
- https://lists.llvm.org/pipermail/llvm-commits/Week-of-Mon-20190826/687838.html
- https://github.com/google/filament/pull/1566


To prevent help weed out bugs before they lead to future miscompilations a new UBSAN check has been added: `nullptr-with-nonzero-offset`
- [UBSan][clang][compiler-rt] Applying non-zero offset to nullptr is undefined behaviour https://reviews.llvm.org/D67122

This new nullptr-with-nonzero-offset check fails on invocations of this macro. Fix the macro to avoid adding to NULL.

__Pyx_KwValues_FASTCALL: avoid triggering UB when adding non-zero to NULL (caught by UBSAN nullptr-with-nonzero-offset)

According to the standard pointer arithmetic is only defined in these situations:
- `nullptr` ± 0 => `nullptr`
- P±N and N±P are pointers that point at an element of the same array with index I±N

`**nullptr**`** + N≠0 is undefined behavior** - even if you don't dereference the resulting pointer.

Since [InstCombine] icmp eq/ne (gep inbounds P, Idx..), null -> icmp eq/ne P, null) https://reviews.llvm.org/D66608 LLVM middle-end uses those guarantees for transformations and mis-compilations have been observed:
- https://lists.llvm.org/pipermail/llvm-commits/Week-of-Mon-20190826/687838.html
- https://github.com/google/filament/pull/1566


To prevent help weed out bugs before they lead to future miscompilations a new UBSAN check has been added: `nullptr-with-nonzero-offset`
- [UBSan][clang][compiler-rt] Applying non-zero offset to nullptr is undefined behaviour https://reviews.llvm.org/D67122

This new nullptr-with-nonzero-offset check fails on invocations of this macro. Fix the macro to avoid adding to NULL.
